message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about the adaptations and behaviors of bears in the arctic. Bears in the arctic can go a long time without eating because they have excess chub, or body fat, which serves as a source of energy during periods when food is scarce. Option (A) and (B) imply that the bear's mental state or determination affects its ability to go without eating, but this is not the case. Option (C) is incorrect because the bear's ability to go without eating is not related to its work or activity level.

This question requires knowledge about the adaptations and behavior of bears in the arctic. Bears in the arctic can go a long time without eating because they have a thick layer of fat called blubber, which acts as insulation and provides energy when food is scarce. This excess chub allows them to survive for extended periods without eating. Options (A), (B), and (C) are not correct because they imply a mental or physical state, but the ability to go a long time without eating is primarily due to the bear's physiological adaptation.

This question requires knowledge about the adaptations of bears in the Arctic. Bears in the arctic can go a long time without eating because they have excess chub, which refers to the layer of fat they accumulate during times of plenty. This layer of fat serves as an energy reserve that sustains them during periods when food is scarce. Options (A), (B), and (C) are incorrect because focus, determination, and work ethic do not directly relate to the bear's ability to survive without eating. It is the presence of excess fat that enables them to go extended periods without food.

This layer of fat serves as a source of energy during the winter when food is scarce. Option (A) and (B) imply personal qualities of the bear, which are not directly related to their ability to go without eating. Option (C) is incorrect because it suggests that the bear needs to work to go without eating, which is not the case.
